questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, presents in spontaneous labor at 38 weeks’ gestation. She is healthy, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has a history of two prior cesarean births—the first for malpresentation and the second was an elective repeat procedure. After extensive counseling, she elects to undergo a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC). An epidural is in place, although she has become more uncomfortable over the past hour. Vital signs are within normal limits, and the most recent cervical exam shows 6 cm dilation, 75% effacement, and 0 station. The fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing shows a baseline rate of 130 bpm, without rapid fluctuations from baseline or visually apparent accelerations. There are recurrent abrupt decreases in FHR of 30 to 60 bpm below baseline that last approximately 30 seconds and begin at the onset of each contraction. Contractions are regular and occur every 2 to 4 minutes. How should this FHR pattern be classified?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in labor in the setting of a TOLAC, and fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing shows absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations, which is classified as a category III FHR tracing. This concerning pattern is associated with fetal acidemia and requires urgent management.

Intrapartum FHR monitoring detects inadequate fetal oxygenation during labor and enables intervention before fetal acidemia causes permanent injury. FHR tracings can be classified as category I, II, or III.

Category I is reassuring and includes only tracings with a normal baseline FHR, moderate variability, and absent late and variable decelerations. On the other hand, category III is associated with fetal acidemia and necessitates prompt evaluation and intervention. Category III is defined by absent variability with either bradycardia or recurrent late or variable decelerations. A sinusoidal pattern, which appears as a smooth sine wave-like pattern (sometimes described as a “sawtooth pattern”) with a cyclic frequency of 3-5 waves per minute, is also considered category III. Finally, category II is considered indeterminate and includes everything not classified as either category I or III.  

Definitions, interpretations, and management of these categories are outlined in the table.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Category I:
Incorrect: Category I is reassuring and is defined by a normal baseline FHR, moderate variability, and the absence of late or variable decelerations. In this case, the recurrent variable decelerations in the setting of absent variability are particularly concerning and would be considered category III.
❌ Category II:
Incorrect: Category II is considered indeterminate and includes patterns that do not meet criteria for either category I or III. In this case, the recurrent variable decelerations in the setting of absent variability are particularly concerning and would be considered category III.
✅ Category III:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reactive:
Incorrect: A “reactive” pattern is defined by the presence of at least two accelerations of at least 15 bpm lasting at least 15 seconds within a 20-minute period. Accelerations are not present in this vignette.
❌ Indeterminate:
Incorrect: Indeterminate patterns are classified as category II. Recurrent variable decelerations with absent variability are abnormal and are classified as category III.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravid woman presents in labor at 38 weeks’ gestation. Her membranes have grossly ruptured, and she is having contractions every 30 minutes. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has a history of chronic hypertension managed with nifedipine. Labor is progressing spontaneously, and she has an epidural in place. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 128/92 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. She appears well, and cervical exam reveals 7 cm dilation with 80% effacement, and the fetal vertex is at 0 station. The baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) is 150 bpm with beat-to-beat variability of 10 bpm. There are no accelerations. The patient soon develops recurrent decelerations with each contraction that descend abruptly and become progressively deeper. Contractions are now occurring every 2 to 3 minutes. The nurse repositions the patient and administers an IV fluid bolus with no improvement in the decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Variable decelerations are caused by umbilical cord compression. An amnioinfusion could help relieve pressure on the umbilical cord and is the best next step in managing the patient in this vignette. An amnioinfusion refers to an infusion of sterile saline into the uterine cavity through an intrauterine pressure catheter (IUPC), cushioning the umbilical cord.  

Labor management is guided by the fetal heart rate (FHR) category. Category I tracings are reassuring and can be managed with routine care. On the other hand, category III tracings are abnormal and require prompt resuscitation and delivery if there is an inadequate response.

Category II tracings indicate an indeterminate fetal well-being and warrant further evaluation. Patients with these tracings should first be assessed for the presence of accelerations and moderate variability, both of which are associated with a normal fetal acid-base status. When these reassuring features are present, intrauterine resuscitation is usually appropriate. This can include repositioning the patient, administering an IV fluid bolus, and, in cases of recurrent variable decelerations, performing an amnioinfusion. Additionally, patients should be assessed for signs of infection, abruption, cord accident, or maternal hypotension and treated accordingly if any are found.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Amnioinfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supplemental oxygen:
Incorrect: Supplemental oxygen does not improve fetal outcomes and is no longer recommended as part of routine intrauterine resuscitation in patients with a normal oxygen saturation.
❌ Tocolysis:
Incorrect: Tocolysis can be considered for patients not receiving uterotonic agents who develop tachysystole and category II tracings. It may also be appropriate for category III tracings, prolonged decelerations, or bradycardia. Tachysystole is defined as > 5 contractions in a 10-minute period---more than the patient is having in this vignette.
❌ Vibroacoustic stimulation:
Incorrect: Vibroacoustic stimulation (VAS) is used to evaluate fetal status in patients with a category II tracing that lacks accelerations and shows minimal or absent variability. If an acceleration occurs or variability increases after VAS, this indicates a lower risk of fetal acidemia. In this patient, the moderate variability is reassuring, making amnioinfusion the preferred next step.
❌ Consider prompt delivery:
Incorrect: Prompt delivery should be considered when fetal well-being cannot be confirmed or when FHR patterns suggest fetal acidemia. This patient has moderate variability, which indicates a low risk of fetal acidemia, making prompt delivery inappropriate.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient, gravida 3, para 2, presents to the obstetrical office at 14 weeks estimated gestation age (EGA) based on her last menstrual period. She has chosen to pursue an elective abortion. Her past medical history includes heavy menstrual bleeding, anemia, and a hemorrhagic ovarian cyst. Vitals are within normal limits. A chaperoned exam shows an enlarged uterus, and a bedside ultrasound confirms a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with her estimated due date. The patient prefers to avoid an overnight hospital admission because she has two small children at home. Which of the following management options should be discussed with the patient as the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
This patient is at 14 weeks EGA and prefers an elective abortion without an overnight hospital stay. Medication abortion at home is generally only available through 10 weeks’ gestation. Although medication abortions can be performed beyond that timeframe, they carry a higher risk of severe bleeding and other complications, which is why patients undergoing second-trimester medication abortion are usually admitted to the hospital. Therefore, a procedural abortion via uterine evacuation is most appropriate for this patient.        

Procedural abortion can be performed in the office or operating room using uterine aspiration and suction curettage or, at more advanced gestational ages, by dilation and evacuation (D&E). Before a D&E, misoprostol or mifepristone may be given to help soften and dilate the cervix, reducing the risks associated with mechanical dilation during the procedure. In addition, antibiotics, specifically doxycycline, are indicated prior to any procedural abortion to reduce the risk of infection.        

Elective abortions are extremely safe, especially in the first trimester when the vast majority occur. In the United States, approximately 90% of induced abortions occur in the first trimester; fewer than 10% occur between 13 and 20 weeks, and fewer than 1% occur after 20 weeks’ gestation. 



Option Analysis

✅ Uterine evacuation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Misoprostol alone:
Incorrect: While misoprostol alone can be used in some circumstances, it is less effective than the combination of mifepristone and misoprostol. Additionally, this patient is beyond 10 weeks EGA, so a procedural abortion is generally preferred. 
❌ Mifepristone and misoprostol:
Incorrect: The combination of mifepristone and misoprostol is the most effective method for a medication abortion, but it is generally for pregnancies up to 10 weeks' gestation. At 14 weeks EGA, a procedural abortion is more appropriate. 
❌ Intrauterine device (IUD) placement:
Incorrect: While an IUD can be used for emergency contraception, it is not considered a reliable method for inducing an abortion. It is an excellent option for post-abortion contraception, but it cannot be placed until elective abortion is complete. An IUD can be placed at the time of a procedural abortion or as early as 1 week after a medication abortion. 
❌ Complete blood count (CBC):
Incorrect: Although checking a CBC can be useful in evaluating a patient with heavy menstrual bleeding or anemia, it is not a required step in the management of an elective abortion in this context.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the obstetrical office with concerns about feeling down. The patient delivered a healthy term infant via vaginal delivery 8 weeks ago; the delivery was complicated by a postpartum hemorrhage that did not require a blood transfusion. The pregnancy was also complicated by mild anemia and advanced maternal age. Today, the patient reports feeling depressed, experiencing fatigue, difficulty concentrating, insomnia, and weight gain over the past 2 weeks. The patient has not had anxiety or excessive worry and reports no suicidal or homicidal ideation. The patient also notes that her supportive partner returned to work 4 weeks ago, and she does not have anyone else to help in the area. Past medical history is significant for a pregnancy loss at 16 weeks and hypothyroidism with normal thyroid function tests last week. Physical examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s depressed mood, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, insomnia, and weight gain are consistent with postpartum depression. A poor social support network is her greatest risk factor for this condition. Other risk factors for postpartum depression include a history of intimate partner violence, a personal or family history of depression or anxiety, and current military service or veteran status.        

Perinatal depression and anxiety affect many patients during pregnancy and up to a year after childbirth. Screening for, diagnosing, and treating these conditions is important because they are associated with adverse maternal and fetal outcomes. Screening is performed using a validated tool, such as the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS), which is most often used during pregnancy and postpartum because it assesses for both depression and anxiety and includes a question about self-harm. Screening should be conducted at the first prenatal visit, during the third trimester, and again postpartum. For patients with risk factors, such as a poor social support network, screening can be performed more frequently.       

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

✅ Poor social network:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Postpartum hemorrhage :
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with postpartum depression. While a postpartum hemorrhage and other pregnancy complications can be risk factors for postpartum anxiety, they are not considered risk factors for postpartum depression. 
❌ Advanced maternal age :
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with postpartum depression. Advanced maternal age (AMA) is associated with several obstetrical complications, such as miscarriage, hypertensive disorders, and gestational diabetes. However, AMA is not a risk factor for postpartum depression. 
❌ History of pregnancy loss:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with postpartum depression. While a history of pregnancy loss is a risk factor for postpartum anxiety, it is not considered a risk factor for postpartum depression. 
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: While hypothyroidism can mimic depression symptoms, this patient’s recent normal thyroid function tests indicate that it is a less likely cause of her condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old G3P1112 woman presents for a 6-week postpartum visit. The patient had an uncomplicated repeat cesarean delivery following a pregnancy complicated by gestational diabetes managed with diet and exercise. There is a history of preterm delivery at 34 weeks due to preterm rupture of membranes with cord prolapse that required an emergent cesarean delivery. Since delivery, the patient reports excessive anxiety and worry, along with irritability, restlessness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. Similar symptoms occurred after the first delivery but resolved after six months without intervention. The patient reports no other history of anxiety or depression. Vital signs are within normal limits, and a chaperoned examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Perinatal anxiety is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient’s symptoms of excessive anxiety and worry, irritability, restlessness, and difficulty concentrating for more than two weeks. A standardized screening tool, such as the General Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7) or Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) with positive anxiety indicators, can aid in confirming the diagnosis.        

Patients with perinatal anxiety present during pregnancy or within the first 12 months after delivery with symptoms similar to generalized anxiety disorder. These symptoms include excessive anxiety and worry along with at least three of the following: restlessness or feeling on edge, fatigue, difficulty concentrating or a mind that goes blank, irritability, muscle tension, or sleep disturbances. Risk factors include personal or family history of anxiety, prior pregnancy loss, an unplanned or complicated pregnancy, intimate partner violence, or a history of childhood abuse.       

Perinatal anxiety is a predictor for perinatal depression. Treatment includes self-care measures such as adequate sleep, exercise, and balanced nutrition. Both psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy are effective first-line treatments, with added benefits when used together. Psychotherapy includes cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT). The preferred pharmacotherapy is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); sertraline is often preferred, although escitalopram is an acceptable alternative. Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine, can also be used. While benzodiazepines are often used for anxiety outside of pregnancy, they should be used sparingly in perinatal anxiety and only as a temporary bridge until psychotherapy, SSRIs, or SNRIs take full effect. A collaborative treatment approach may involve a mental health professional and, if indicated, hospitalization.    

Option Analysis

✅ Perinatal anxiety:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mild perinatal depression (postpartum blues):
Incorrect: Mild perinatal depression, or postpartum blues, typically occurs within 2 days up to 2 weeks after delivery. Symptoms include dysphoric mood, crying, mood lability, anxiety, sleeplessness, loss of appetite, and irritability. This patient’s symptoms have persisted beyond 2 weeks and are more consistent with perinatal anxiety. 
❌ Perinatal depression:
Incorrect: Although fatigue and concentration difficulties are present, the predominant symptoms—excessive anxiety, worry, restlessness, and irritability—align more with perinatal anxiety. Continued monitoring is advised, as perinatal anxiety can be a predictor for perinatal depression.  
❌ Postpartum psychosis:
Incorrect: Postpartum psychosis is rare but serious. Symptoms can include agitation, delusions, disorganized thoughts, bizarre behavior, auditory or visual hallucinations, and intrusive thoughts of suicide or infanticide. None of these features are evident here, and the patient’s presentation is more consistent with perinatal anxiety. 
❌ Bipolar disorder:
Incorrect: While it is important to rule out bipolar disorder before starting medication for perinatal depression and anxiety, this patient does not have a history of manic or hypomanic episodes consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 1, presents in labor at 39 weeks’ gestation with an uncomplicated pregnancy. The patient's medical history includes one prior uncomplicated vaginal birth and one septic abortion at 10 weeks’ gestation managed with antibiotics and dilation and curettage (D&C). Labor progresses normally, and the patient delivers a 3,600 g (8 lb) healthy neonate. Immediately after delivery, vital signs are stable, the uterine fundus is firm at the umbilicus, and a second-degree laceration is noted that is slowly oozing blood. Five minutes later, there is a sudden increase in vaginal bleeding. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 84/60 mmHg. The patient's skin is cold and clammy. A bimanual examination reveals a firmly adherent placenta. Intravenous (IV) fluids are initiated, labs are drawn, and O-negative blood is requested. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of blood products as needed based on lab results

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden, massive blood loss in the setting of a firmly adherent placenta following vaginal birth; this presentation suggests placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), in which the placenta abnormally attaches to or invades the uterine wall. PAS can rapidly lead to severe postpartum hemorrhage and shock. A patient in hemorrhagic shock from PAS requires immediate assessment and management of the airway, breathing, and circulation, and should be transferred immediately to the operating room for definitive hemostasis.

Although PAS is often diagnosed on antenatal ultrasound, it may present unexpectedly after delivery. These patients typically have delayed placental delivery and/or severe postpartum hemorrhage during the third stage of labor that does not respond to uterotonic agents. Bleeding can become life-threatening, and patients can rapidly develop signs of shock.

In these situations, vital signs must be closely monitored and intubation performed if there is any evidence of airway compromise. Aggressive resuscitation with IV fluids and blood products should begin and a massive transfusion protocol activated, if available. Temporary measures, such as bimanual uterine compression and administration of uterotonic agents, may help limit bleeding as the patient is transferred to the operating room for D&C or laparotomy. Hysterectomy is often required.

Option Analysis

✅ Transfer to the operating room:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repair of the obstetric laceration:
Incorrect: Blood loss from this obstetric laceration is minimal compared to the hemorrhage coming from the firmly adherent placenta (placenta accreta). This patient should be moved to the operating room for emergent surgical intervention to control the hemorrhage.
❌ Transfusion of blood products as needed based on lab results:
Incorrect: Hemorrhage secondary to placenta accreta can evolve rapidly and quickly become life-threatening. Transfusion is guided by clinical status (e.g. vital signs, symptoms, exam findings) rather than laboratory values. This patient should be moved to the operating room for emergent surgical intervention to control the hemorrhage.
❌ Uterotonic agents and close observation:
Incorrect: Although uterotonic agents may be appropriate to give in this setting, observation alone is insufficient. Hemodynamic instability from placenta accreta necessitates prompt surgical intervention. Therefore, the priority is to transfer the patient to the operating room.
❌ Manual extraction of the placenta:
Incorrect: This patient likely has unexpected placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), indicating that the placenta is firmly adherent to the uterine wall and may be invading into or through the myometrium. Attempts at manual extraction will likely tear the placenta and worsen hemorrhage. Surgical management is required, necessitating transfer to the operating room.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old primigravid woman presents at 16 weeks’ gestation with hematuria. The patient has no dysuria or increased urinary urgency. Medical history is notable for infertility, and the patient conceived following a procedure involving multiple myomectomies and in vitro fertilization. The patient is otherwise healthy and only takes a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears well. There is no uterine or suprapubic tenderness. Speculum exam shows no vaginal bleeding and a closed cervix. An ultrasound demonstrates a single viable fetus and an anterior placenta covering the internal os. There are multiple placental lacunae, loss of the hypoechoic clear zone between the placenta and uterine wall, and retroplacental myometrial thinning. An area of hypervascularity over the posterior bladder wall is noted. Urinalysis results are displayed below. Which of the following strategies would be most appropriate for reducing the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in this patient?

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Urinalysis    
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Blood     3+    
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative    
 Nitrites     Negative

choices.text: Pre-delivery occlusion of the internal iliac arteries
Antenatal medical management of the bladder lesion
Antenatal surgical management of the bladder lesion
Dilation and curettage (D&C) immediately following delivery of the neonate

questions.solution:
This patient with an antenatal diagnosis of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) requires a multidisciplinary team and careful delivery planning to minimize postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and associated complications. Strategies to reduce blood loss include occlusion of the internal iliac arteries (which provide the primary blood supply to the uterus) and the use of Cell Saver technology (to recycle blood lost during the surgery).  

Antenatally, the patient’s hemoglobin should be optimized with iron supplementation. Delivery is best arranged at a tertiary care center between 34 and 36 weeks’ gestation after corticosteroids administration for fetal lung maturation. A planned cesarean hysterectomy is recommended: the infant is delivered first, the placenta remains in situ, and hysterectomy follows. If the placenta invades the bladder, partial cystectomy may be necessary. Prophylactic placement of ureteral stents has been shown to decrease the risk of ureteral injury during cesarean hysterectomy.

Intraoperatively, patients should have at least 2 large bore IVs placed and cross-matched blood readily available for transfusion. Antifibrinolytic therapy (e.g. tranexamic acid) may be administered in cases of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or severe hemorrhage.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pre-delivery occlusion of the internal iliac arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antenatal medical management of the bladder lesion:
Incorrect: This patient has placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) with bladder invasion. Definitive management requires cesarean hysterectomy and partial cystectomy to remove the entire placenta. PAS does not resolve with antenatal medical management.
❌ Antenatal surgical management of the bladder lesion:
Incorrect: This patient has placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) with bladder invasion. Definitive management requires cesarean hysterectomy and partial cystectomy to remove the entire placenta. Attempting antenatal surgical management would be inappropriate because invasive placental tissue cannot be safely resected before delivery.
❌ Dilation and curettage (D&C) immediately following delivery of the neonate:
Incorrect: This patient has placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) with bladder invasion. Definitive management requires cesarean hysterectomy and partial cystectomy to remove the entire placenta. D&C may be utilized in patients with smaller, focal areas of abnormal placental attachment, unlike the patient described here.
❌ Antenatal iron supplementation:
Incorrect: Antenatal iron supplementation is recommended in most patients with placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) to maximize hemoglobin concentration prior to delivery. However, it does not independently reduce the risk of PPH.

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old woman presents to the OB-GYN clinic 48 hours postpartum with fever, lower abdominal pain, and foul-smelling vaginal bleeding that has been worsening. Labor lasted 20 hours and was followed by a cesarean birth due to fetal distress. Intrapartum antibiotics were administered for group B Streptococcus (GBS) prophylaxis. The patient is taking only prenatal vitamins and has no known drug allergies. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The abdominal examination reveals mild suprapubic tenderness, and the uterine fundus is markedly tender on palpation. There is foul-smelling purulent lochia. A complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell (WBC) count of 18,000/µL with a left shift. Urinalysis and urine culture are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of fever, lower abdominal pain, a tender uterine fundus, and foul-smelling lochia two days postpartum, along with a history of prolonged labor and cesarean delivery, is highly suggestive of postpartum endometritis. The diagnosis is typically clinical and can be made based on history and physical examination after ruling out a urinary tract infection. Additional diagnostic testing is not required, and prompt initiation of empiric antibiotic therapy is essential to reduce the risk of progression to sepsis.

The differential diagnosis of postpartum fever includes endometritis, pyelonephritis, surgical site infections, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), septic pelvic thrombophlebitis, and lactational mastitis. The timing of fever onset can help narrow the differential. When the diagnosis is unclear, further testing such as a complete blood count (CBC), urinalysis, urine culture, or imaging studies may be appropriate.

In this case, the timing, clinical presentation, and negative urinalysis point towards endometritis as the most likely diagnosis. Additional evaluation is only necessary if there is no improvement with empiric treatment.


Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial culture:
Incorrect: Although endometrial culture can help identify the causative organism, it is not routinely obtained in the evaluation and management of postpartum endometritis. Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started promptly, covering skin, vaginal, and gastrointestinal flora.
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound is useful for identifying retained products of conception (POC), but it is not required when the clinical presentation is typical for postpartum endometritis. Retained POC is extremely uncommon following cesarean birth due to the nature of the procedure
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT scan may be indicated in cases where there is suspicion of other intra-abdominal pathology, including septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. However, this patient’s presentation is classic for endometritis. Further imaging is not required.
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: While blood cultures can be useful in patients with systemic signs of sepsis, they are not necessary for the initial diagnosis and management of postpartum endometritis, where prompt empiric antibiotic therapy should be initiated based on clinical presentation.
✅ Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with left calf pain that began 2 days ago. The patient reports returning from an 8-hour road trip a day before the onset of symptoms. There is no history of trauma or blood clots. Past medical history is significant for obesity, and the patient is not currently on any medication. There is no significant family history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the left calf is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation, with a 3 cm difference in circumference compared to the right calf. A lower extremity compression ultrasound of the left iliac vein shows poor compressibility. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT), confirmed by poor compressibility on a lower extremity compression ultrasound. The most appropriate initial management for DVT during pregnancy is low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), which effectively prevents clot extension and embolization while remaining safe for both the pregnant person and the fetus.   

Medical management of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in pregnancy primarily involves anticoagulation therapy, with LMWH being preferred due to its safety profile and ease of use. LMWH does not require frequent monitoring and carries a lower risk of osteoporosis and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia compared to unfractionated heparin.    

Vitamin K antagonists, such as warfarin, cross the placenta and are generally avoided during pregnancy due to the risk of teratogenicity and fetal hemorrhage. Direct oral anticoagulants, including direct thrombin inhibitors and factor-Xa inhibitors, have insufficient safety data in pregnancy and are thus not recommended.    

Treatment with LMWH typically continues for at least 3 months and should extend through at least 6 weeks postpartum, a period associated with increased thrombotic risk. If long-term anticoagulation is required after delivery, therapy may be transitioned to warfarin, which is considered safe during breastfeeding.   

Option Analysis

✅ Low molecular weight heparin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Vitamin K antagonist  :
Incorrect: Vitamin K antagonists, such as warfarin, are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects, especially in the first trimester, and the risk of fetal hemorrhage. These agents can cross the placenta and negatively impact fetal development. 
❌ Oral direct thrombin inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Oral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, are not recommended in pregnancy due to the lack of sufficient safety data and unknown effects on the fetus. 
❌ Factor-Xa inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Factor-Xa inhibitors, including rivaroxaban and apixaban, should be avoided in pregnancy because of insufficient data regarding their safety and potential risks to the developing fetus.  
❌ Daily aspirin :
Incorrect: Aspirin is not sufficient for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). While it may have a role in the prevention of certain thrombotic conditions, it does not provide the necessary anticoagulant effect required to treat an active thrombus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation comes to the emergency room in active labor. She has had routine prenatal care. Medical history is significant for gestational diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. She delivers a 4kg male baby. A 2nd-degree perineal tear is noted. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this injury?
questions.solution:
This patient has a second-degree perineal tear following a difficult childbirth. A second-degree perineal tear involves injury to the perineal body.    

Perineal tears are a common obstetric injury following difficult vaginal childbirth. They are distinct from an episiotomy, an intentional enlargement of the vaginal introitus to facilitate delivery.  

An episiotomy is a surgical incision that involves the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. Episiotomies are done to minimize perineal injuries caused by overstretching the perineum by the fetal head; however, they are not routinely indicated.  Possible indications for an episiotomy include conditions when the physician anticipates a perineal tear, elderly primigravida, macrosomia, face to pubis delivery, forceps/ventouse delivery, breech delivery, or shoulder dystocia.    

There are two common approaches to an episiotomy; a mediolateral approach and a median approach.  In a mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made at an angle and proceeds from the vaginal opening diagonally downwards to the left or the right in a straight line that runs an inch away from the anus.  During a mediolateral episiotomy, structures incised include the posterior vaginal wall, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin.  

In the median episiotomy, the incision proceeds from the vaginal opening downwards. Median episiotomies bifurcate the perineal body, which supports the female pelvic organs, particularly the posterior vaginal wall. Incision of the perineal body poses a risk of pelvic organ prolapse and urinary incontinence. Midline episiotomies can also extend into the anal sphincter and cause sphincter dysfunction and fecal incontinence.  





Option Analysis

✅ Perineal body :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anal mucosa:
Incorrect: Fourth-degree perineal tears involve the anal sphincter complex and the anal mucosa. Second-degree perineal tears are limited to the perineal skin and the perineal body.   
❌ Ischiocavernosus muscle :
Incorrect: The ischiocavernosus muscle is a component of the urogenital triangle and the superficial perineal pouch. It arises from the ischial tuberosity and inserts into the crura of the clitoris. It is unlikely to be involved in second-degree perineal tears.   
❌ Internal anal sphincter :
Incorrect: The anal sphincter complex (internal anal sphincter and the external anal sphincter) are damaged in fourth-degree perineal lacerations.   
❌ External anal sphincter :
Incorrect: Severe perineal lacerations of the third and fourth degrees tend to involve the external anal sphincter and result in fecal incontinence.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, at 8 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent nausea and vomiting. The patient states that she has had difficulty tolerating oral intake and her symptoms have been interfering with her job as a software engineer. She has tried dietary modifications and switched to an iron-free prenatal vitamin without relief. She has no abdominal pain or urinary symptoms. The patient has no significant past medical history and is otherwise healthy, but did have similar symptoms during her previous two pregnancies. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/60 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. BMI is 22 kg/m².  The patient has steadily been gaining the appropriate amount of weight during this pregnancy. Physical examination reveals moist mucous membranes with normal abdominal and cardiopulmonary examination. Urinalysis is negative for ketones. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy. She has moderate symptoms of persistent nausea and vomiting with difficulty tolerating oral intake. Dietary modifications and switching to an iron-free prenatal vitamin have not helped her symptoms. Treatment with pyridoxine and doxylamine is the most appropriate management at this time.    

Patients with mild symptoms typically have intermittent nausea and/or vomiting and have normal vital signs and laboratory results. Milder forms of the disease do not typically require pharmacologic therapy and can be managed with lifestyle modifications. These include dietary changes, such as eating small, frequent meals, incorporating high-protein snacks throughout the day, and avoiding spicy or fatty foods. In addition, patients can take an iron-free prenatal vitamin and be counseled on trigger avoidance (e.g. loud sounds, lights).    

Patients like this one with moderate symptoms of persistent nausea and vomiting typically require pharmacological management to help them tolerate fluid and food intake. First-line therapy includes pyridoxine and doxylamine. Patients with refractory symptoms can be treated with alternative pharmacologic therapy including diphenhydramine or promethazine.  

Patients with severe symptoms are unable to tolerate oral intake, demonstrate persistent nausea and vomiting, may have weight loss, and often have evidence of dehydration on physical examination including dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. These patients are also likely to have electrolyte abnormalities including hypokalemia, and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, and if ketonuria is present they may be diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidarum. Patients with severe symptoms require hospitalization for initiation of pharmacotherapy including ondansetron, rehydration, and electrolyte repletion. 


Option Analysis

✅ Pyridoxine and doxylamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ondansetron:
Incorrect: Ondansetron is typically used in patients who are hospitalized with hypovolemia from severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy or in patients with persistent vomiting resistant to pyridoxine and doxylamine, diphenhydramine or dimenhydrinate, and promethazine.
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Patients with moderate symptoms and vomiting that are not responsive to pyridoxine and doxylamine can be started on diphenhydramine or dimenhydrinate.
❌ Intravenous normal saline:
Incorrect: This patient has no evidence of dehydration and does not have hyperemesis gravidarum. Administration of normal saline is not necessary at this time and this patient should be started on pyridoxine and doxylamine. 
❌ Promethazine:
Incorrect: Patients with moderate symptoms that are not relieved with pyridoxine and doxylamine and diphenhydramine or dimenhydrinate can be given promethazine.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G4P4 woman is evaluated for vaginal bleeding immediately following spontaneous vaginal delivery of a baby boy at 38 weeks gestation. The placenta is delivered without problems and appears intact on gross examination. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication daily. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated. She has three other living children who were delivered without complications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and anxious. There are no vaginal or cervical lacerations or hematomas. There is evidence of continued, profuse vaginal bleeding from the cervical os without evidence of masses in the endometrium. On a bimanual exam, the uterus feels boggy and soft. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform uterine massage and increase the dose of oxytocin
Place tamponade balloon or vacuum-induced suction

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of immediate postpartum hemorrhage which is a potentially life-threatening condition for which there can be a variety of causes. The examination findings of a boggy and soft uterus are suggestive of uterine atony, which is the most common cause of immediate postpartum hemorrhage. It can be immediately treated with uterine massage and compression along with administration of uterotonic agents (e.g. oxytocin, carboprost).

Postpartum hemorrhage refers to bleeding after delivery that results in either a cumulative blood loss of at least 1000 mL or blood loss associated with signs and symptoms of hypovolemia. Immediate, or primary postpartum hemorrhage occurs in the first 24 hours following delivery, while delayed, or secondary postpartum hemorrhage occurs more than 24 hours to 12 weeks following delivery. All postpartum hemorrhages are obstetric emergencies and require timely recognition and management.

The acute management of immediate postpartum hemorrhage involves stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation with a focus on hemorrhage control and determining the cause of bleeding. Patients should have large bore IV access established, empiric crystalloid administration for hypotension/hemodynamic instability, as well as blood type and crossmatch sent for the administration of blood products. Patients found to have a soft boggy uterus should receive uterine massage and uterotonic agents such as oxytocin. Tranexamic acid and prostaglandin or methylergonovine should be given if immediate measures to not stop the bleeding are unsuccessful.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Perform uterine massage and increase the dose of oxytocin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer tranexamic acid:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid (TXA) is an antifibrinolytic agent and should be considered for treatment of hemorrhage due to atony if uterine massage and increasing the dose of oxytocin is not effective at controlling the bleeding.  
❌ Administer fresh frozen plasma:
Incorrect: Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) should be considered for patients with concerns about disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). This patient's presentation is more consistent with hemorrhage from uterine atony.  
❌ Place tamponade balloon or vacuum-induced suction:
Incorrect: These methods of controlling bleeding should be considered when uterotonic agents, tranexamic acid, and fundal massage have been unsuccessful at controlling bleeding.  
❌ Hysterectomy:
Incorrect: Hysterectomy should be considered only for treatment of postpartum hemorrhage that is refractory to all other treatments.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of vaginal bleeding for one day. The patient has had low grade fevers for two days, has been passing a number of large clots vaginally, and has a malodorous vaginal discharge. The patient delivered a healthy baby-boy two weeks ago via cesarean section at 37-weeks gestation. This patient's pregnancy was complicated by prolonged rupture of membranes. The patient has no previous medical history. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 112/67 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is well-appearing. Physical examination reveals a well healing Pfannenstiel incision without evidence of infection. Uterine tenderness is present on a bimanual exam and purulent vaginal discharge is seen. Urinalysis is negative. Laboratory studies are obtained and pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation for secondary postpartum hemorrhage. Endometritis, which is an infectious inflammation of the endometrium, can lead to postpartum hemorrhage. Risk factors include c-section, prolonged labor, and prolonged rupture of the membranes. The findings of malodorous vaginal discharge, fever, and uterine tenderness in this patient are highly suggestive of endometritis. This patient is well-appearing and has a low-grade fever, therefore, empiric treatment with ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole should be started.

Primary postpartum hemorrhage occurs in the first 24 hours following delivery, while delayed, or secondary postpartum hemorrhage occurs more than 24 hours to 12 weeks following delivery. History, physical exam, and lab work can help determine the cause. Blood Work should include CBC, PT, PTT, and INR, and in cases of fever a urinalysis. Endometritis should be suspected in cases of fever and uterine tenderness in patients without any other source of fever. Empiric antibiotics should be started, and pelvic ultrasound may be performed as well if indicated.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pelvic ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasonography may be performed if the diagnosis of endometritis is uncertain or if symptoms persist despite appropriate treatment, to rule out retained tissue and other issues. This patient's history and examination are consistent with endometritis, and therefore she should start on empiric antibiotics initially.  
❌ MRI pelvis:
Incorrect: MRI pelvis is not indicated in the diagnostic workup of delayed postpartum hemorrhage or suspected endometritis.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: Blood cultures are typically not necessary in the evaluation and management of mild to moderate endometritis. They can be helpful in severe cases or in cases that do not improve with appropriate antibiotics.  
❌ Urine culture:
Incorrect: Urine cultures are not necessary in the initial evaluation and treatment of mild to moderate endometritis. Also, this patient has a normal urinalysis. If this patient is non-clinically improving after 48 hours of antibiotics, then blood and urine cultures should be taken.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided pelvic pain for the last week and light vaginal spotting. Today, the pain became severe, and the patient subsequently developed lightheadedness. The patient has not had a fever or vomiting. She had pelvic inflammatory disease two years ago and is currently sexually active with one biologically male partner. Her periods are irregular, and she reports that her last normal menstrual cycle was three months ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 88/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient appears pale and in pain. There is diffuse abdominal tenderness with rebound tenderness and guarding. Serum hCG is 3,900 IU/L. Ultrasound shows evidence of an adnexal mass and free fluid in the pelvis. There is no intrauterine pregnancy visualized. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe pelvic pain, hypotension, and a positive hCG without the presence of an intrauterine pregnancy on ultrasound. These findings, along with free fluid in the pelvis, suggest a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Emergent laparoscopy is indicated to control the bleeding and remove the damaged tissue. The patient’s preceding symptoms of unilateral pelvic pain and vaginal bleeding were likely symptoms of the ectopic pregnancy prior to rupture. Previous pelvic inflammatory disease is a risk factor for ectopic pregnancy.   

The first step in assessing patients with acute pelvic pain is to establish stability. Findings of hypotension and tachycardia are concerning for internal bleeding from an etiology such as a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Ectopic pregnancy represents one of the true gynecologic emergencies that can cause acute pelvic pain in a biological female. It occurs when an embryo implants outside of the uterine cavity, usually in the fallopian tube. As the fetus grows, the fallopian tube is unable to accommodate the growing fetus, leading to rupture. Patients typically present with significant abdominal and pelvic pain, syncope or lightheadedness, with or without recent vaginal bleeding. In the presence of rupture, the abdominal exam typically shows rebound tenderness and guarding. Emergent surgery is the only option for management after rupture occurs; however, less invasive treatment with methotrexate may be considered if the ectopic pregnancy is found prior to rupture in select circumstances.  



Option Analysis

✅ Laparoscopy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate can be used in a small subset of patients with ectopic pregnancy who meet the following criteria: hemodynamic stability, no suspicion of impending or active tubal rupture, low and declining serum hCG levels, no fetal cardiac activity, capability of close follow up, and no contraindications to methotrexate therapy. This patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of a tubal rupture and is therefore not a candidate for methotrexate therapy.
❌ Local feticidal injection:
Incorrect: Feticidal injection is occasionally used to manage an unruptured ectopic pregnancy when there is a concurrent intrauterine pregnancy which is being preserved. This patient is unstable with a likely ruptured ectopic pregnancy requiring emergent surgery.
❌ Salpingostomy:
Incorrect: Salpingostomy involves incising the fallopian tube and removing the tubal pregnancy while leaving the remaining tube intact. Salpingostomy is an option for patients with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. This patient has evidence of tubal rupture.  
❌ Hysterectomy :
Incorrect: A hysterectomy is not routinely indicated for patients with a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A newly pregnant 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at seven weeks of gestation by last menstrual period comes to the emergency department with a six-hour history of vaginal bleeding and worsening menstrual-like cramps. She reports soaking through two menstrual pads an hour for the last four hours, passing several large clots, and is now feeling lightheaded and nauseous. The past medical history is noncontributory, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. The family history is significant for two uncomplicated spontaneous early pregnancy losses in her mother. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mmHg. On exam, the patient is noted to be pale with delayed capillary refill. Several large clots are removed from the vagina on speculum exam, and the external cervical os is open. Labs are drawn and pending. A bedside pelvic ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac with a yolk sac and an 8 mm fetal pole without fetal cardiac activity. In addition to supportive care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Check serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level
Let patient preference guide the management decision

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an incomplete miscarriage complicated by hemodynamic instability due to hemorrhage. The patient is feeling lightheaded and has tachycardia, hypotension, and signs of excessive blood loss on exam. After initial stabilization, the next step is to manage the hemorrhage via emergent surgical evacuation of the uterus.   

Incomplete miscarriage refers to a pregnancy loss that is currently in progress: the cervical os is open and the patient is actively bleeding/passing tissue, but the ultrasound still shows products of conception in the uterus. The amount of bleeding during a spontaneous pregnancy loss can vary significantly, and although uncommon, some patients can have substantial bleeding leading to hemorrhagic shock.  

In all hemodynamically unstable patients, the first step is to address the airway, breathing, and circulation with supportive care, which may include intubation, assisted ventilation, IV fluids, a blood transfusion, and/or vasopressors as needed. The next critical step is to stop the hemorrhage by evacuating the uterus. Because the patient is unstable, this should be done as soon as possible, which requires surgical intervention with a suction dilation and curettage.   

When patients are hemodynamically unstable, care should not be delayed while awaiting hCG results. Additionally, in acute hemorrhage, the CBC values may not accurately reflect the degree of current blood loss, so it is important to use the entire clinical picture to guide resuscitation efforts. Finally, it is important to administer Rh-immune globulin to any Rh-negative patients who undergo surgical management of early pregnancy loss.  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform emergent surgical uterine evacuation:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Check serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level :
Incorrect: HCG levels are used to follow early pregnancies of undetermined location before they are visible on ultrasound. This patient already has a known intrauterine pregnancy and is hemodynamically unstable, so she requires urgent uterine evacuation to stop the bleeding regardless of the hCG results.
❌ Continue supportive care:
Incorrect: Expectant management is appropriate for most hemodynamically stable patients who prefer this option, though it is more successful when used in patients with incomplete miscarriages compared to asymptomatic (“missed”) losses. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable and, therefore, requires stabilization and urgent uterine evacuation to staunch the hemorrhage. 
❌ Prescribe misoprostol:
Incorrect: Medical management is appropriate for most hemodynamically stable patients who prefer this option. This patient is hemodynamically unstable and, therefore, requires stabilization and urgent uterine evacuation to staunch the hemorrhage.
❌ Let patient preference guide the management decision:
Incorrect: For most hemodynamically stable patients, management should be based on patient preference. Expectant and medical management both take significantly longer to complete, and medical management is associated with higher rates of blood loss than surgical management. Surgical management is recommended for patients with hemodynamic instability, conditions that cannot tolerate significant drops in hemoglobin, or pelvic infections/sepsis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 6 weeks of gestation by last menstrual period presents to the emergency department with bleeding and menstrual-like cramping that has been getting progressively worse over the last 8 hours. The patient’s previous pregnancies were uncomplicated and delivered vaginally at term. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. On speculum exam, the external cervical os is open, and a large blood clot is visible within the cervical canal. An ultrasound shows a 16 mm fluid collection containing a 5 mm echogenic ring within the uterus and a 2 cm simple unilocular cyst is seen in the left ovary; no fetal pole is seen. A serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level is 2,600 mIU/mL. Which of the following should be discussed with the patient regarding her pregnancy?

choices.text: Pregnancy loss has already been completed.
It is too early to determine if the pregnancy will continue or not.
Suction dilation and curettage is needed.

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with inevitable pregnancy loss because the cervical os is already open and there is evidence of retained products of conception within the uterus. In this case, the patient should be counseled on the inevitability of pregnancy loss.   

In the vignette, the 16 mm intrauterine fluid collection represents a normal gestational sac, the 5 mm echogenic ring represents a normal yolk sac, and the 2 cm simple ovarian cyst represents a normal corpus luteal cyst. These cysts, generally less than 2.5 cm in diameter, secrete progesterone that is vital to the success of early pregnancies and should not be confused with an ectopic pregnancy.  

The diagnostic evaluation of a pregnant patient with vaginal bleeding in the first trimester always includes a history, physical exam, and an ultrasound. A serum human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level is also critical at early gestational ages but is generally irrelevant if the patient already has a previously established intrauterine pregnancy with fetal cardiac activity (FCA). This is because the rate of hCG increase slows as the pregnancy progresses and ultimately plateaus around 10 weeks, and normal values can vary widely after FCA is established. Therefore, after FCA is identified on ultrasound, FCA is used to follow viability rather than hCG trends. The physical exam and ultrasound findings can be used to determine the diagnosis, which then guides further management. Patients with inevitable pregnancy loss should be managed expectantly and offered supportive care, including resources such as grief counseling or chaplain services to support their mental health.  


Option Analysis

✅ Pregnancy loss is inevitable.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pregnancy loss has already been completed.:
Incorrect: A complete miscarriage is diagnosed when a patient presents with bleeding and/or cramping and has a closed cervical os on exam with an empty uterus on ultrasound. This patient has an open os and retained products of conception. The intrauterine fluid collection represents the gestational sac and the echogenic ring represents the yolk sac.
❌ It is too early to determine if the pregnancy will continue or not.:
Incorrect: This patient has an open cervical os, so pregnancy loss is inevitable. The ultrasound findings could potentially represent viable findings, so this answer would have been correct if the cervical os was closed.
❌ Suction dilation and curettage is needed.:
Incorrect: Suction dilation and curettage (D&C) is only needed in patients with hemodynamic instability or sepsis. It is also appropriate in stable patients who prefer this management option. This patient is hemodynamically stable and does not show signs of sepsis or pelvic infection (e.g. uterine tenderness, purulent discharge, fever). She has an inevitable pregnancy loss that can be managed expectantly.
❌ Laparoscopy may be required.:
Incorrect: Laparoscopy, along with methotrexate, are options for managing ectopic pregnancies. A confirmed intrauterine pregnancy (conceived naturally) effectively excludes an ectopic pregnancy. This patient’s ultrasound findings represent a gestational sac containing a yolk sac within the uterus (confirming pregnancy location) and a normal corpus luteal cyst in the left ovary. She has an inevitable pregnancy loss that can be managed expectantly.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old G1P0 woman at 15 weeks gestation presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of fatigue for the past three weeks. She has had minimal pregnancy-associated weight gain secondary to daily nausea and vomiting multiple times a day. The nausea and vomiting have improved since she entered the second trimester, and she currently has nausea with vomiting several times each week. Current medications include prenatal vitamins. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is comfortable and in no acute distress. There is no tenderness to palpation of the abdomen, and she has a gravid uterus appropriate for gestational age. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?  

 Laboratory Test  Serum Value 
 Hemoglobin  10 g/dL 
 MCV  75 fL 
 Iron  39 mcg/dL 
 Ferritin  9 ng/mL 
 Total Iron Binding Capacity  427 mcg/dL 
 Vitamin B12  500 pg/mL 
 Folate  10.0 ng/mL
questions.solution:
This patient with microcytic anemia, low serum iron, low ferritin, and high total iron-binding capacity has iron deficiency anemia. While oral supplementation every other day is typically appropriate treatment for iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy, this patient still has regular vomiting, making intravenous iron supplementation more appropriate.  

Pregnant patients with concern for anemia should have a complete blood count obtained, which will provide the hemoglobin and mean corpuscular volume (MCV). Based on these results, further studies should be performed to determine the cause of anemia. Iron deficiency anemia leads to low serum iron, low ferritin (iron stores), and high total iron-binding capacity. Transferrin saturation is also typically low. Ferritin will be low and may be the first iron study to become abnormal in patients with iron deficiency anemia. Patients with iron deficiency anemia should also be evaluated to rule out blood loss as the cause. If a pregnant patient with microcytic anemia has a normal ferritin or normal iron studies, then an alternative diagnosis, such as hemoglobinopathies or thalassemia, should be suspected.  

Patients with iron deficiency anemia should be given oral iron supplementation three times weekly on an empty stomach with vitamin C. However, for patients who cannot tolerate oral iron or those with malabsorption or severe anemia, intravenous iron can be used initially. For patients where iron deficiency anemia does not improve with oral iron supplementation, intravenous iron should be given. After one month, the CBC can be repeated to assess response.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous iron :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral iron :
Incorrect: This patient still is still vomiting multiple times a week, and oral supplements may lead to more nausea and vomiting with little absorption.
❌ Intramuscular B12:
Incorrect: Intramuscular B12 can be used to treat patients with severe refractory B12 deficiency or for those who cannot tolerate oral vitamin B12. This patient has microcytic anemia from iron deficiency requiring iron supplementation, and she has a normal vitamin B12 level.
❌ Oral B12:
Incorrect: This patient has a microcytic anemia from iron deficiency requiring iron supplementation, and she has a normal vitamin B12 level.
❌ Oral folate:
Incorrect: This patient has a microcytic anemia from iron deficiency requiring iron supplementation, and she has a normal folate level.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, at 35 3/7 weeks of gestation presents 20 minutes after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure at home. She has never had a seizure before. She notes that the convulsions were preceded by a headache with blurred vision. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 180/116 mmHg. On exam, the patient is alert, oriented, and conversing easily. Hyperreflexia of the deep tendons is present, but no focal neurologic deficits are appreciated. The fetal heart rate pattern is reassuring, and no contractions are noted on cardiotocographic monitoring. An intravenous (IV) line is placed, and labs are drawn. The patient is given a dose of IV labetalol, and a repeat blood pressure is 154/86. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient had a witnessed seizure in the setting of severe hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation without a clear alternative cause and, therefore, meets criteria for eclampsia. Patients with eclampsia are at high risk for recurrent seizures and maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. Therefore, she should be started on magnesium sulfate immediately for seizure prophylaxis.

Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy exist on a spectrum, which includes gestational hypertension, preeclampsia without or with severe features, HELLP syndrome, and eclampsia. The presence of severe range blood pressures, warning symptoms, or specific lab findings identify severe disease. HELLP syndrome is distinguished from preeclampsia with severe features when the combination of hemolysis (elevated LDH), elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets are all present; while eclampsia refers to patients on this spectrum who have seizures.

Patients with severe hypertension in pregnancy, defined as ≥ 160 systolic or ≥ 110 diastolic, have hypertensive urgency and are at high risk of complications, including stroke and placental abruption. These patients require immediate treatment with anti-hypertensive agents to lower their BP out of the severe range. IV labetalol or IV hydralazine are the preferred agents; however, oral nifedipine can also be used if IV access is unavailable.

Patients with HELLP syndrome and eclampsia should be started on IV magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis and be delivered immediately (e.g. within 24 hours of diagnosis). Vaginal delivery is preferred unless the patient has a contraindication to this route (e.g. malpresentation). If a patient seizes while on magnesium, they can receive an additional bolus of magnesium and/or be treated with a benzodiazepine. Patients with preeclampsia with severe features can be managed expectantly as inpatients until 34 weeks and delivered at 34 weeks (or as soon as diagnosed if further along). They should receive magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis intrapartum. Finally, all patients being treated with magnesium sulfate require close maternal and fetal monitoring and careful fluid management to avoid pulmonary edema.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV magnesium sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Repeat dose of IV labetalol:
Incorrect: Only severe range blood pressures (i.e. ≥ 160 systolic or ≥ 110 diastolic) require treatment with IV anti-hypertensive agents. This patient’s blood pressure is no longer in the severe range; therefore, she does not need an additional dose of an IV anti-hypertensive agent. She should have IV magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis.  
❌ Emergent cesarean delivery:
Incorrect: Delivery is indicated in patients like this one who have eclampsia; however, vaginal delivery is preferred if there are no contraindications to that route (e.g. malpresentation) and the patient is stable enough to proceed. This patient should have IV magnesium sulfate first for seizure prophylaxis to prevent another seizure.  
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: It is appropriate to offer corticosteroids for fetal maturation to late preterm patients (i.e. those between 34 and 36 6/7 weeks) at high risk of birth within 7 days and before 37 weeks of gestation. Delivery is indicated at the time of diagnosis in eclampsia, so this patient will deliver before 37 weeks. However, starting IV magnesium sulfate is the priority to prevent recurrent seizures that would carry substantial maternal and fetal risks.  
❌ Focused obstetric ultrasound:
Incorrect: A focused obstetric ultrasound will provide additional confirmation of fetal well-being and the fetal position, which has implications regarding the route of delivery. However, performing a focused obstetric ultrasound is a lower priority than starting IV magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1 at 12 weeks of gestation, presents to the clinic for her first prenatal visit. The patient reports feeling well and has no concerns. Her first child, delivered two years ago, had a birth weight of 3.2 kg (7 lbs). She has a history of irregular menstrual cycles and was diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) five years ago. Family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in a first cousin. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Blood pressure is 135/85 mm/Hg. Body mass index is 25 kg/m2. The rest of the vitals and physical exam are within normal limits. Which of the following features of this patient’s history or physical exam indicates the need for early screening for gestational diabetes mellitus?

choices.text: Type 2 diabetes in a first cousin

questions.solution:
This pregnant woman presenting for her initial prenatal care visit has a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) which increases her risk of developing GDM. Given that she has a BMI ≥ 25 and an additional risk factor for GDM, she should undergo early screening for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Women with PCOS are at increased risk of developing GDM due to the underlying insulin resistance associated with the condition.  

Screening for GDM in women with PCOS is important for managing both maternal and fetal health. Early identification and management of GDM can help prevent complications such as preeclampsia and macrosomia. If patients have no previous diagnosis of diabetes mellitus, then the next step is to assess whether they are at high risk for GDM. The

American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology recommends that patients with a BMI ≥ 25 (≥ 23 in Asian Americans), and one or more additional risk factors for gestational diabetes be screened early for GDM. Additional risk factors include a history of GDM in a previous pregnancy; a first-degree relative with diabetes (e.g., parent, sibling); previous delivery of an infant weighing at least 4,000 grams or about 9 pounds; and a personal history of polycystic ovarian syndrome or cardiovascular disease.



Option Analysis

❌ Blood pressure of 135/85 mm/Hg:
Incorrect: Given this patient’s BMI of 25 kg/m2, if another risk factor is present, which would include hypertension (Blood pressure ≥ 140/90 or current treatment for hypertension), then early screening would be indicated.
❌ Age of 27 years:
Incorrect: Advanced maternal age (>35 years) is a risk factor for gestational diabetes. This patient’s age does not significantly increase the risk of developing gestational diabetes and therefore, does not indicate the need for early screening.
✅ Polycystic ovarian syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Delivery of a 7-pound baby:
Incorrect: The birth weight of her first child was 7 pounds or 3.2 kg, which is within the normal range. Prior delivery of a baby with macrosomia (birth weight ≥ 4,000 grams) is associated with gestational diabetes and would warrant early screening.
❌ Type 2 diabetes in a first cousin:
Incorrect: The most significant family history that increases the risk for gestational diabetes is having a first-degree relative,( ie parent or sibling), with type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1 at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine prenatal care. She has no significant past medical history and her first pregnancy was uncomplicated. The patient undergoes a 50-gram glucose challenge test and the 1-hour plasma glucose level is 145 mg/dL. A 100-gram oral glucose tolerance test is performed and shows the following glucose values: fasting95 mg/dL, 1-hour 190 mg/dL, 2-hour 155 mg/dL, and 3-hour 145 mg/dL. The patient subsequently undergoes intensive dietary modifications and initiates regular moderate physical activity. Her self-monitoring of blood glucose shows postprandial glucose levels ranging from 95-115 mg/dL. Based on these results, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue with dietary modifications and regular moderate physical activity
Repeat oral glucose tolerance testing in 4 weeks
Increase the frequency of prenatal visits to weekly

questions.solution:
The patient's 100-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) results indicate gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), as two of the values meet or exceed the Carpenter and Coustan criteria (fasting <95 mg/dL, 1-hour <180 mg/dL, 2-hour <155 mg/dL, 3-hour <140 mg/dL). In this case, the patient's fasting glucose is normal, but the 1-hour and 2-hour values are elevated. After initiating dietary and lifestyle modifications, she demonstrates good glucose control. This classifies her condition as A1 GDM, which can be managed with lifestyle modifications  including dietary changes, physical activity, and self-monitoring of glucose levels without the need for medication.  

A1 and A2 are classifications of GDM that help guide management strategies based on the severity of the condition. A1 GDM is diagnosed when glycemic control is achieved through diet and exercise alone without medication. Women with A1 GDM do not require medication and management focuses on lifestyle modifications, including intensive nutritional counseling and regular moderate physical activity to maintain blood glucose within the target range. Commonly used antepartum glycemic targets are one-hour postprandial blood glucose concentration <140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) and two-hour postprandial glucose concentration <120 mg/dL (6.7 mmol/L).  

A2 GDM represents a more severe form of GDM, where blood glucose levels remain high despite dietary and lifestyle changes, and glycemic control is achieved with medications. A2 GDM should be managed with pharmacological interventions such as insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents. A2 GDM is associated with a higher risk of pregnancy-related complications, requiring more intensive monitoring and management compared to A1 GDM.

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate insulin therapy:
Incorrect: This patient’s gestational diabetes (GDM) is classified as A1, indicating that blood glucose levels are elevated but can be controlled with dietary modifications and physical activity alone. This patient has adequate glucose control with initial diet and lifestyle interventions and should continue current management. Insulin therapy is indicated for A2 GDM or for cases of A1 GDM that do not respond adequately to dietary and lifestyle interventions.
✅ Continue with dietary modifications and regular moderate physical activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repeat oral glucose tolerance testing in 4 weeks:
Incorrect: While daily self-monitoring of blood glucose is an essential part of managing diagnosed gestational diabetes mellitus, retesting with an oral glucose tolerance test in 4 weeks is not indicated once the diagnosis is established. The focus should now be on monitoring and management rather than retesting.
❌ Prescribe oral hypoglycemic agents:
Incorrect: The initial management of A1 gestational diabetes (GDM), characterized by blood glucose levels that are elevated but controllable with diet and exercise, does not involve the use of oral hypoglycemic agents. These medications, such as glyburide, are used to treat A2 GDM.
❌ Increase the frequency of prenatal visits to weekly:
Incorrect: Increasing the frequency of prenatal visits to weekly, is not typically required for managing A1 gestational diabetes mellitus, where blood glucose levels can be controlled with diet and exercise.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2P1, presents to the emergency department with progressive, right sided, lower abdominal pain for the past 18 hours and light vaginal spotting. The pain is sharp and intermittent. She does not have fever, chills, diarrhea, dysuria, dizziness, or shoulder pain. She has had mild nausea without vomiting for the past two weeks. Her last menstrual period was seven weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner without the use of contraception. Past surgical history is significant for appendectomy at age 10. She had one vaginal delivery two years ago and was treated for a chlamydia infection three years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination reveals a 6 cm uterus, right adnexal fullness without a discrete mass, and cervical motion tenderness. Qualitative hCG is positive. Which of the following would most likely be seen with serial quantitative hCG testing?

choices.text: Initial hCG level of 2,100 mIU/mL, hCG level of 2,550 mIU/mL after 48 hours
Initial hCG level of 200,000 mIU/mL and 358,000 mIU/mL after 48 hours

questions.solution:
This patient presents seven weeks after her last menstrual period with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting and with pelvic examination findings of right adnexal fullness and cervical motion tenderness (indicating pelvic pathology). The most likely diagnosis is a tubal ectopic pregnancy, which is the most common type of ectopic pregnancy. This patient has several risk factors for ectopic pregnancy, including previous abdominal surgery and a previous STI. An initial hCG level of 2,100 mIU/mL that increases to 2,550 mIU/mL after 48 hours would be consistent with this diagnosis.    

HCG is produced by placental trophoblast cells. In the presence of a normal pregnancy, levels should rise by at least 53% in 48 hours and double every 48 to 72 hours until reaching a peak at 10 weeks. Since there is significant variability in the levels, the pattern of change is very important. In an ectopic pregnancy, serial hCG levels rise more slowly than expected in a normal pregnancy, and they may plateau or even decrease. However, in about one third of ectopic pregnancies, hCG levels may rise appropriately.    

Falling or abnormally rising serum levels of hCG are diagnostic of an abnormal early pregnancy, either a failed intrauterine gestation or an ectopic pregnancy. It is important to consider clinical context, ultrasound findings, along with the level and trend of hCG over time.       

Option Analysis

❌  Initial hCG level of 8,700 mIU/mL, hcG level of 15,660 mIU/mL after 48 hours  :
Incorrect: These hCG levels can be seen with a threatened miscarriage, where there is normal increase in hCG consistent with normal pregnancy but vaginal bleeding through a closed cervical os is present. In a threatened miscarriage, hCG levels can rise appropriately with at least a 53% rise in 48 hours, similar to a normal pregnancy. However, this patient’s clinical presentation and pelvic examination findings suggest an ectopic pregnancy.  
✅ Initial hCG level of 2,100 mIU/mL, hCG level of 2,550 mIU/mL after 48 hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initial hCG level of 1,200 mIU/mL, hCG level of 1,080 mIU/L after 48 hours :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a missed miscarriage where the fetus has either not developed or has been lost but has not been expelled from the uterus. hCG levels may be lower than expected at a specific gestational age, may not double appropriately and may plateau or decrease. This patient’s clinical presentation suggests an ectopic pregnancy.
