❌  Initial hCG level of 3,250 mIU/mL, hCG level of 1,625 mIU/mL after 48 hours :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a complete miscarriage, which occurs when all pregnancy tissue has been expelled. HCG falling by 50% is consistent with the absence of any hCG producing tissue and the known half-life of hCG. This patient’s clinical presentation suggests an ectopic pregnancy. 
❌ Initial hCG level of 200,000 mIU/mL and 358,000 mIU/mL after 48 hours:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a molar pregnancy where abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic tissue causes significantly higher than expected levels of hCG for a specific gestational age as well as hCG levels that are rising faster than expected.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, is admitted to the hospital in labor and ready to begin pushing. Her previous pregnancies resulted in spontaneous vaginal deliveries of infants whose birth weights were normal. Her body mass index (BMI) prior to pregnancy was 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her cervix is 10 cm dilated, 100% effaced, and grossly ruptured membranes. The fetal head delivers after 130 minutes but immediately retracts against the perineum. Gentle downward traction of the head does not deliver the shoulders. Which of the following clinical features, if present, would be the strongest risk factor for the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: 35 lb. of maternal weight gain during pregnancy
A prolonged active phase of labor
Delivery at 41 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA)

questions.solution:
This woman, who presents with retraction of the fetal head against the perineum (turtle sign) and with shoulders that do not deliver with gentle downward traction, has shoulder dystocia. This is an obstetric emergency caused by impaction of the fetal shoulders on the bony pelvis, preventing delivery of the body after delivery of the head. Gestational diabetes (GDM) more than doubles the risk of shoulder dystocia compared to non-diabetic individuals.    

Other major risk factors include a history of prior delivery complicated by shoulder dystocia and fetal macrosomia, which is defined as a fetus with an estimated fetal weight of > 4000 to 4500 grams (definitions vary). Conditions associated with macrosomia are also generally considered risk factors for shoulder dystocia, including GDM, obesity, excessive maternal weight gain, and post-term pregnancy. Importantly, GDM also increases the risk of a higher fetal shoulder-to-head ratio, further increasing the risk regardless of fetal weight. Intrapartum, a prolonged second stage of labor, and assisted vaginal delivery (e.g., forceps or vacuum) are both associated to lesser degrees than with other conditions with shoulder dystocia.        

Despite these known risk factors, there is no way to accurately predict when shoulder dystocia will occur. In 50% of cases, no risk factors are identified, and birthweight is <4000 grams. In addition, most patients with risk factors do not experience shoulder dystocia. However, physicians should be more vigilant when any risk factors are present.       

Option Analysis

❌ 35 lb. of maternal weight gain during pregnancy :
Incorrect: Obesity and excessive maternal weight gain are modest risk factors for shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. However, in a patient like this one with a normal pre-pregnancy BMI, 25 to 35 lbs. of weight gain is recommended, so 35 lbs. of weight gain would be normal for this patient and not be a risk factor for shoulder dystocia.  
❌ A prolonged active phase of labor :
Incorrect: A prolonged 2nd stage of labor, not active phase, should raise suspicion of shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. There is no significant link between shoulder dystocia and a prolonged active phase, referring to dilation from 6 to 10 cm in the first stage of labor.  
❌ Delivery at 41 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA):
Incorrect: Post-term pregnancy, defined as pregnancy extending beyond 42 weeks EGA, is associated with an increased risk of shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. However, at term, gestational diabetes would be a more significant risk factor for shoulder dystocia than an EGA of 41 weeks. 
✅ Gestational diabetes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gestational hypertension:
Incorrect: Gestational hypertension is not associated with shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy are more often associated with fetal growth restriction, which reduces the risk of shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2 at 41 weeks' gestation, is undergoing induction of labor for pre-labor rupture of membranes (PROM). She experienced rupture of membranes 24 hours ago, and spontaneous labor did not occur with expectant management. She has received regular prenatal care, and this pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her previous pregnancy was also uncomplicated and resulted in a vaginal delivery of an infant at term whose weight was within normal limits. Past medical and surgical histories are unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is 10 cm dilated and 100% effaced. The presentation is cephalic at station 0 cm. After 20 minutes of pushing, the head delivers. The shoulders do not deliver with gentle downward traction. Which of the following clinical signs is indicative of the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the patient in the vignette is consistent with shoulder dystocia, which is a clinical diagnosis made when the fetal shoulders fail to deliver with gentle downward traction of the fetal head, and additional maneuvers are required to effect delivery of the body. The presence of the turtle sign is indicative of shoulder dystocia and describes the retraction of the fetal head against the perineum. The name comes from the resemblance to a turtle withdrawing into its shell.    

Shoulder dystocia occurs when the anterior shoulder becomes impacted behind the mother’s symphysis pubis or, less commonly, when the posterior shoulder becomes impacted on the sacral promontory, preventing further fetal descent. In this position, the fetal chest and abdomen are compressed within the pelvis, preventing both expansion of the lungs and perfusion through the umbilical cord, which can rapidly lead to fetal hypoxia.    

Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency that requires prompt recognition and management to prevent neonatal complications such as brachial plexus injury or fetal asphyxia. All obstetrical care providers should be prepared for potential shoulder dystocia at every delivery, as 50% of patients with shoulder dystocia have no identifiable risk factors.    

Option Analysis

❌ Chadwick sign:
Incorrect: Chadwick sign is the bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina from increased vascularity of the stroma. It is often seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. Although pregnancy-related, it is not related to shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. 
❌ Goodell sign:
Incorrect: The Goodell sign describes the softening of the pregnant cervix from edema. It is a normal early sign of pregnancy detected with palpation. It is not associated with shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis. 
✅ Turtle sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acanthosis nigricans:
Incorrect: Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques in intertriginous areas. It is associated with insulin resistance. Although gestational diabetes is a risk factor for shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis in the vignette, acanthosis nigricans, is not diagnostic of shoulder dystocia.
❌ Homan sign:
Incorrect: The Homan sign refers to calf pain with dorsiflexion of the foot. It can indicate deep vein thrombosis. Although pregnant women are at a higher risk of venous thromboembolism when compared to non-pregnant women, there is no connection to shoulder dystocia, the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 37 weeks of gestation is in labor for an anticipated spontaneous vaginal delivery and is found to have a fever. Contractions are occuring every five minutes. Labor has been complicated by prolonged rupture of membranes. The pregnancy has otherwise been uncomplicated. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and is the same when taken 30 minutes later, heart rate is 110 bpm, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination demonstrates fundal tenderness. Monitoring demonstrates a fetal heart rate of 170 bpm. Which of the following clinical factors in this case indicates the need for treatment with antibiotics?
questions.solution:
This patient at 37 weeks of gestation who is in labor is found to have a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) and fundal tenderness. The presence of a fever 38.0°C (100.4°F) to 38.9°C (102.02°F) on ≥ 2 measurements 30 minutes (apart without another clear source of infection) PLUS at least one of the following: fetal tachycardia (FHR > 160), maternal leukocytosis (WBC > 15,000), or purulent fluid from cervical os is diagnostic for intraamniotic infection and indicates a need for treatment with antibiotics.

Patients may have symptoms of fundal tenderness, malaise, and tactile fevers, and they will typically have at least one risk factor for the development of intraamniotic infection. Physical examination may reveal purulent fluid from cervical os or fundal tenderness. Diagnosis is made if maternal temperature exceeds 39.0°C or if temperature is 38.0°C to 38.9°C and at least one of the following is present: fetal tachycardia (FHR > 160), maternal leukocytosis (WBC > 15,000), or purulent fluid from cervical os.

Patients who meet diagnostic criteria for an intraamniotic infection should receive empiric antibiotic therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin with the addition of metronidazole if the patient is undergoing cesarean delivery. Patients with a temperature between 38.0°C and 38.9°C with or without a persistent temperature elevation 30 minutes later and without other clinical findings indicating intraamniotic infection are considered to have an isolated maternal fever. Management can include antibiotic therapy or observation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Fetal heart rate of 170 bpm:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal heart rate of 110 bpm:
Incorrect: Fetal tachycardia, not maternal tachycardia, is a clinically significant factor used to diagnose and treat intraamniotic infection. Fetal tachycardia is defined as fetal heart rate >160 bpm.  
❌ Anticipated spontaneous delivery:
Incorrect: The anticipated route of delivery is not used to make a diagnosis of intraamniotic infection. 
❌ Presence of fundal tenderness:
Incorrect: Fundal tenderness is a non-specific finding in patients with intraamniotic infection. The presence of fundal tenderness should raise suspicion for intraamniotic infection, and other findings should be used to determine the diagnosis and need for antibiotics. 
❌ Gestational age of 37 weeks:
Incorrect: Gestational age is not a clinically significant factor for determining the need for antibiotics in patients with suspected intraamniotic infection.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 2, aborta 1, at 6 weeks gestational age by last menstrual period, presents to the emergency department with left lower quadrant pain and vaginal bleeding. She and her partner have been trying to conceive and had a positive home pregnancy test last week. Her initial antenatal appointment is scheduled for next week. Past medical history is notable for two uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal deliveries and one ruptured ectopic pregnancy treated with a right salpingectomy 6 years ago. She also has a history of endometriosis and mild intermittent asthma requiring the use of albuterol 2 to 3 times per month. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.7 °F), heart rate is 86 bpm, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg. Weight is 125 pounds. The exam is notable for left adnexal tenderness and a small amount of bright red blood in the vaginal vault. Labs are obtained, with results shown below. A transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterine cavity and a 3.2 cm complex left adnexal mass. Neither a gestational sac, yolk sac, nor embryo are visible. Which of the following clinical factors indicates the need for surgical management in this patient? 
 
 Lab values      Results   
 Hemoglobin      12.1  g/dL    
 Total leukocyte count     7500/mm³    
 Platelet count     87,000/mm³    
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)     23 mg/dL    
 Creatinine     1.3  mg/dL    
 Aspartate aminotransferase      20 U/L    
 Human Chorionic gonadotropin     4200 mIU/ml
questions.solution:
This patient can be diagnosed clinically with an ectopic pregnancy based on the ultrasound showing an empty uterine cavity in the setting of an HCG above the discriminatory level of 3500 mIU/mL. Her abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and sonographically visible complex adnexal mass also support the diagnosis. This patient has moderate thrombocytopenia (platelet count between 50 and 99,000/mm3), which is an absolute contraindication to methotrexate, and therefore, surgical management is indicated.

An ectopic pregnancy is a gestation that has implanted outside the uterine cavity; it is a non-viable pregnancy that can lead to life-threatening hemorrhage if it ruptures. Treatment options include medical management with methotrexate (MTX) and surgical management with either a salpingectomy or salpingostomy. Patients with a contraindication to methotrexate require surgical management. Factors associated with increased rates of MTX failure are also considered relative contraindications, including an initial HCG > 5000 mIU/mL, an adnexal mass > 4 cm, and embryonic cardiac activity.

The table below reviews clinical factors that can be used to determine the appropriate treatment modality. Appropriate candidates for MTX treatment should be counseled on both MTX and surgical options, and the final decision regarding treatment modality should rest with the patient. Rh-immune globulin is also indicated for all Rh-negative patients.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Thrombocytopenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ HCG level:
Incorrect: An initial HCG level above 5,000 mIU/mL is a relative contraindication to methotrexate (MTX) because it is associated with higher rates of MTX failure. MTX may still be appropriate in well-counseled, motivated patients who prefer this method. 
❌ History of asthma:
Incorrect: Active pulmonary disease, except for asthma, is a contraindication to methotrexate. This is because MTX affects rapidly dividing cells, including the respiratory epithelium, but asthma is a disease caused by airway hyperresponsiveness. Therefore, methotrexate is not contraindicated. 
❌ Size of the adnexal mass:
Incorrect: Ectopic pregnancy size > 4 cm on transvaginal ultrasound is a relative contraindication to methotrexate (MTX) because it is associated with higher rates of MTX failure. MTX may still be appropriate for well-counseled, motivated patients who prefer this method. 
❌ Creatinine level:
Incorrect: An intermediate methotrexate dose is used to treat ectopic pregnancy. The dose can be adjusted based on creatinine clearance, and it should be avoided in patients with very low creatinine clearance. This patient’s creatinine clearance is 54 mL/min and methotrexate is safe to use without renal dose adjustment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, presents to labor and delivery triage at 26 weeks of gestation with painless vaginal bleeding that began 2 hours ago. She has saturated about 50% of a pad already. An anatomy ultrasound at 20 weeks of gestation showed an anatomically normal fetus, a posterior placenta with the lower margin located 8 mm from the internal cervical os, a velamentous cord insertion, and umbilical vessels passing within 14 mm of the os. Her medical history is notable for three prior C-sections that were uncomplicated. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. A speculum examination shows a very slow trickle of bright red blood coming from a closed cervical os. The fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing shows a baseline of 130/min with no accelerations or decelerations and a saw-tooth, sinusoidal pattern, and there are no contractions seen on the monitor. Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan?

choices.text: Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 32 weeks
Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 34 weeks
Outpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
The patient in the vignette is presenting with vasa previa, a low-lying placenta, and acute bleeding. Vasa previa is diagnosed when the fetal umbilical vessels pass within 20 mm of the internal cervical os. Placenta previa is diagnosed when the placenta overlies the os, whereas a low-lying placenta does not cover but is within 20 mm of the os.  Blood loss from vasa previa originates from the fetus and can result in rapid fetal exsanguination, whereas blood loss from placenta previa comes from the pregnant person. In this vignette, the maternal vital signs are stable, but a sinusoidal FHR pattern is present, indicating severe fetal anemia and significant fetal distress. Therefore, an emergent C-section is indicated because the fetus is unstable.         

The first step in the acute management of painless antenatal bleeding is to assess the stability of both the patient and the fetus. Emergent C-section to control the hemorrhage is indicated if either the fetus or the pregnant person is unstable. To assess the pregnant person, a primary survey is performed, and an initial set of vital signs is obtained. Management of hemorrhagic shock in the pregnant person includes standard resuscitation measures, with attention to the airway, breathing, and circulation, and IV fluids and blood products as needed. The fetus is assessed with cardiotocographic monitoring and an ultrasound. The primary sign of an unstable fetus is an FHR pattern indicating severe distress, such as bradycardia or a sinusoidal pattern.    

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent C-section now:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 32 weeks:
Incorrect: This patient has a known vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss.  The sinusoidal FHR pattern in the vignette indicates an unstable fetus with severe fetal anemia. The fetus is exsanguinating and an emergent C-section should be performed.  
❌  Inpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 34 weeks:
Incorrect: This plan is appropriate for stable mother-fetus dyads with a vasa previa. This patient has a known vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss. The sinusoidal FHR pattern in the vignette indicates the fetus is unstable and has severe fetal anemia. Emergent C-section is indicated. 
❌ Outpatient monitoring until a scheduled C-section at 37 weeks:
Incorrect:  This plan is appropriate for stable mother-fetus dyads with placenta previa. The patient in the vignette has a vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss. The sinusoidal FHR pattern indicates the fetus is unstable and has severe fetal anemia. Emergent C-section is indicated. 
❌ Outpatient monitoring until spontaneous labor:
Incorrect: This plan is appropriate for stable mother-fetus dyads with a low-lying placenta that is 11 to 20 mm from the internal os. The patient in the vignette has a vasa previa and presents with acute fetal blood loss. The sinusoidal FHR pattern indicates the fetus is unstable and has severe fetal anemia. Emergent C-section is indicated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 37 weeks of gestational age, presents for induction of labor for gestational hypertension. She has no headaches, visual changes, shortness of breath, or right upper quadrant pain. Her first delivery was a cesarean birth due to breech presentation at term, and her second delivery was an uncomplicated vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). Her blood pressure on admission is 140/84 mm Hg, and her cervix is less than 1 cm dilated, thick, and high. Maternal-fetal cardiotocographic monitoring shows a baseline fetal heart rate of 140 bpm, moderate variability, and no accelerations, decelerations, or contractions. An ultrasound confirms the fetus is in a vertex presentation, and a single deepest vertical pocket of fluid is 3.5 cm. A urinalysis shows trace proteinuria and serum blood work is unremarkable. Which of the following should be part of her intrapartum management?

choices.text: Avoidance of a Foley balloon for cervical ripening
Fetal scalp electrode during the active phase of labor
Intrauterine pressure catheter during the active phase of labor

questions.solution:
This patient presents for induction of labor (IOL) with an unfavorable cervix and a history of a prior cesarean birth. Cervical ripening is needed, but prostaglandins are contraindicated in patients undergoing a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) due to the increased risk of uterine rupture. For these patients, mechanical ripening with a Foley balloon and/or judicious use of oxytocin is preferred for cervical ripening. Despite this patient's need for an IOL, her prior history of successful VBAC makes her a good candidate for TOLAC, with appropriate management.        

The most significant risk associated with TOLAC is uterine rupture, which is an obstetric emergency requiring an emergent cesarean birth. For this reason, patients undergoing TOLAC should have an IV placed on admission and continuous maternal-fetal cardiotocographic monitoring throughout labor. Anesthesia providers, a surgical team, and an operating suite must all be immediately available. As mentioned above, prostaglandins for cervical ripening are contraindicated. Additionally, although acceptable for use in patients undergoing TOLAC, oxytocin should only be used judiciously, at the lowest effective dose, because it also increases the risk of uterine rupture.    

Option Analysis

✅ Avoidance of prostaglandins:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Intrapartum magnesium sulfate is indicated in patients with preeclampsia with severe features, HELLP syndrome, and eclampsia. This patient lacks severe features, and therefore magnesium sulfate is not indicated. 
❌ Avoidance of a Foley balloon for cervical ripening:
Incorrect: During a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), a Foley balloon could be used for mechanical cervical ripening. It is usually used in conjunction with judicious use of oxytocin because prostaglandins are contraindicated during TOLAC. 
❌ Fetal scalp electrode during the active phase of labor:
Incorrect: During a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), both the parturient and fetus must be continually monitored to immediately detect evidence of a uterine rupture. However, external monitors are appropriate without the need for a fetal scalp electrode. 
❌ Intrauterine pressure catheter during the active phase of labor:
Incorrect: During a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), both the parturient and fetus must be continually monitored to immediately detect evidence of a uterine rupture. However, external monitors are appropriate without the need for an intrauterine pressure catheter.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 0020, at 18 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA), presents for a routine antenatal appointment. Her partner who fathered this pregnancy has an A-positive blood type, while her blood type is O-negative. She had some light vaginal bleeding 4 weeks ago, and an ultrasound in the emergency department (ED) showed a strong fetal heartbeat at the time. She was given an injection, and her bleeding resolved after a few days. She has not had any complications since that time. Her obstetrical history is notable for an ectopic pregnancy treated “with several different types of shots,” followed by a miscarriage at 6 weeks EGA which was diagnosed by an ultrasound showing only a yolk sac without development of a fetal pole. Her miscarriage was treated with “pills only, no shots.” Today, her vital signs are within normal limits, and a physical exam is unremarkable. A type and screen show maternal Rh antibodies are present. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?

choices.text: Recent administration of anti-D immune globulin after light vaginal bleeding
Antibody formation after early pregnancy loss
Antibody formation after the ectopic pregnancy
It is a normal finding when the parents are RhD-discordant

questions.solution:
When assessing a patient with a positive RhD antibody screening test, it is important to determine if that person received anti-D immune globulin within the past 12 weeks, as would be the case for this patient who had a bleeding episode at 14 weeks. Recent anti-D immune globulin administration can result in a positive screening test without true alloimmunization.

Rh alloimmunization refers to the development of maternal antibodies to the Rhesus D antigen present on Rh-positive red blood cells (RBCs). Alloimmunization can occur whenever Rh-negative maternal blood encounters Rh-positive blood; these situations are known as sensitizing events, which are detailed in the box above.

If maternal IgG antibodies develop, they can cross the placenta and attack Rh-positive fetal RBCs, leading to potentially severe fetal anemia, hydrops fetalis, and death. For this reason, anti-D immune globulin is routinely administered to patients after sensitizing events to prevent alloimmunization. Fortunately, alloimmunization is unlikely if these patients are appropriately treated, which is likely what occurred with the patient in this vignette. However, the antibodies can persist and cause a positive antibody screen for up to 12 weeks after administration.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recent administration of anti-D immune globulin after light vaginal bleeding:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Antibody formation after early pregnancy loss:
Incorrect: Maternal antibodies can develop after miscarriage of an Rh-positive fetus. However, before 7.5 weeks EGA, there are not enough (or any) erythrocytes to trigger an immune response. Therefore, the risk of alloimmunization is non-existent after a miscarriage occurs before a fetal pole is present. 
❌ Antibody formation after the ectopic pregnancy:
Incorrect: Bleeding associated with an ectopic pregnancy can trigger the development of maternal anti-RhD antibodies. However, the ectopic pregnancy was treated with “different shots,” likely methotrexate and anti-D immune globulin. With the administration of anti-D immune globulin, alloimmunization would be extremely unlikely. 
❌ Alloimmunization after recent antenatal bleeding:
Incorrect: Although bleeding at 14 weeks EGA can lead to the development of maternal anti-RhD antibodies and alloimmunization, the injection she received in the ED after having vaginal bleeding, likely anti-D immune globulin, is more likely cause of the positive antibody screen. 
❌ It is a normal finding when the parents are RhD-discordant :
Incorrect: A positive antibody screen is not a normal finding with RhD-discordant partners. Maternal IgG antibodies against fetal erythrocyte antigens can cross the placenta, attack fetal erythrocytes, and lead to severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and fetal demise.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 12 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA), presents for a routine prenatal appointment. She has no bleeding, cramping, or abnormal discharge. She had a prior vaginal birth at term, complicated by retained placenta and postpartum hemorrhage that required dilation and curettage and blood transfusion. She has no medical problems, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On exam, the patient is well-appearing with no abdominal tenderness. Laboratory studies show that her blood type is A-negative with a positive antibody screen, while her partner is A-positive with a heterozygous genotype. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Because the presence of anti-D antibodies is only a problem for an Rh-positive fetus, it is crucial to first determine the fetal blood type in Rh-negative women with a positive antibody screen. This can be done through analysis of the paternal blood type, maternal cell-free DNA testing, or a 2nd trimester amniocentesis.

Rh alloimmunization refers to the development of maternal antibodies against the Rhesus D antigen present on Rh-positive red blood cells (RBCs). Maternal IgG anti-D antibodies can cross the placenta and attack Rh-positive fetal RBCs, leading to severe fetal anemia, hydrops fetalis, and death.

Therefore, upon detection of maternal anti-D antibodies, the first step is to determine if the fetus could be Rh-positive based on the paternal blood type. If the father is Rh-positive, genotyping is indicated. If the father is homozygous, the fetus will also be Rh-positive and is at risk of hemolytic disease. However, if the father is heterozygous, there is only a 50% chance the fetus is Rh-positive. In this situation, as seen in the vignette, determining the fetal blood type is the best next step. If the fetus is Rh-negative, the fetus is not at risk of hemolytic disease, and routine care is appropriate.    

Option Analysis

✅ Cell-free DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Anti-D antibody titer:
Incorrect: With a paternal heterozygous genotype, it is possible that the fetus is Rh-negative. Therefore, the first step is to determine the fetal blood type with cell-free DNA testing because the maternal anti-D antibodies will not be a problem if the fetus is Rh-negative. 
❌ Middle cerebral artery (MCA) Doppler velocimetry:
Incorrect: MCA Dopplers are used as a screening test for fetal anemia. They are indicated if the fetus is (or could be) Rh-positive and at risk for hemolytic disease due to maternal anti-D antibodies. In this patient, the fetal blood type should first be determined with cell-free DNA. 
❌ Cord blood sampling:
Incorrect: Cord blood sampling is an invasive procedure used to assess fetal hematocrit. It is indicated when severe anemia is suspected based on the results of MCA Doppler screening. However, severe anemia due to hemolytic disease is only possible if the fetus is Rh-positive; therefore, cell-free DNA testing to determine the fetal blood type should be performed first. 
❌ Kleihauer-Betke (KB) test :
Incorrect: A KB test is used to determine the volume of fetal blood present in maternal serum after a sensitizing event with the potential for a large fetal-maternal hemorrhage, such as intrauterine fetal death or abdominal trauma. The patient in the vignette lacks these indications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 38 weeks of gestational age, presents after a sudden large gush of fluid from the vagina approximately 45 minutes ago. Approximately 10 minutes after the loss of fluid, she began having contractions every 2 minutes. The pain has now worsened and has become constant. The pregnancy has been complicated by pregestational diabetes mellitus managed with insulin, polyhydramnios, and fetal growth restriction (FGR). She has a history of two prior uncomplicated vaginal deliveries at term. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg. A speculum exam shows the accumulation of bloody fluid in the vaginal vault, and the cervix is visually 2 cm dilated. The uterus is firm and tender to palpation. The fetal heart rate is in the 110s, with contractions every 2 minutes. U-shaped decelerations are noted with each contraction; the nadir of the decelerations occurs after the peak of the contraction. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Sudden decompression of the uterus caused the placenta to shear off the uterine wall
Elevation of maternal insulin levels led to premature weakening of fetal membranes
Overdistended uterus led to concurrent rupture of the uterine wall and fetal membranes.

questions.solution:
In a pregnant patient presenting with ruptured membranes in combination with vaginal bleeding, constant abdominal pain, and fetal distress; placental abruption should be considered. Placental abruption refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall. The sudden decompression of the uterus that can occur with membrane rupture can generate shearing forces that lead to placental abruption. In this patient, polyhydramnios combined with FGR suggests that there could have been significant decompression of the uterus with membrane rupture.        

When membrane rupture occurs before the onset of contractions, it is referred to as prelabor rupture of membranes (PROM). Patients typically describe “a gush of fluid” before the onset of contractions, though PROM often triggers the start of normal labor at term. The exam will often demonstrate the accumulation of straw-colored amniotic fluid in the vaginal vault, known as pooling. Small amounts of “bloody show” and contractions are normal findings in labor; however, constant abdominal pain, heavy bleeding, and abnormalities in the fetal heart rate pattern are not normal findings and suggest placental abruption.    

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden decompression of the uterus caused the placenta to shear off the uterine wall:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Initiation of normal labor :
Incorrect: Although cervical dilation can produce “bloody show,” the patient’s constant abdominal pain, frequent contractions, and late decelerations are not normal findings and suggest a placental abruption. 
❌ Elevation of maternal insulin levels led to premature weakening of fetal membranes :
Incorrect: Maternal insulin levels are not directly associated with prelabor rupture of membranes.  
❌ Umbilical cord prolapse led to lacerated umbilical cord :
Incorrect: A prolapsed umbilical cord is seen or felt as a pulsating cord-like structure within the vagina or cervix, which is not present in this vignette. This patient’s constant abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding after membrane rupture are more concerning for placental abruption. 
❌ Overdistended uterus led to concurrent rupture of the uterine wall and fetal membranes.:
Incorrect: Although an overdistended uterus may lead to uterine rupture, this is extremely uncommon in a patient like this one with an unscarred uterus. Placental abruption following prelabor rupture of membranes is more likely.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravid woman presents for a routine antenatal visit at 28 weeks of estimated gestational age (EGA). She has no contractions, vaginal bleeding, loss of fluid, decreased fetal movement, headache, vision changes, shortness of breath, or upper abdominal pain today. Her pregnancy has been complicated by pre-gestational diabetes mellitus type 1, well-controlled on an insulin pump. Her only other medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/92 mmHg. The symphysis-to-fundal height measures 25 cm. A recent growth ultrasound showed a single viable infant in the breech presentation with an estimated fetal weight (EFW) at the 6th percentile. What type of antepartum fetal surveillance is indicated for this patient?

choices.text: Biophysical profile (BPP) and umbilical artery (UA) Doppler velocimetry
Non-stress test (NST) and amniotic fluid volume (AFV) assessment
Antepartum fetal surveillance is not indicated in this patient
Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) assessment and umbilical artery (UA) Doppler velocimetry

questions.solution:
Patients like the one in this vignette, where the estimated fetal weight is below the 10th percentile for gestational age, are considered to have fetal growth restriction (FGR). These patients should have antepartum fetal surveillance with both a biophysical profile (BPP) and umbilical artery Doppler velocimetry study. 

Antepartum fetal surveillance is used to evaluate fetal well-being in patients where there is an increased risk of stillbirth, as there is with fetal growth restriction. The testing is meant to detect fetal distress early, allowing time to intervene before worsening hypoxemia and metabolic acidosis result in fetal demise. However, it cannot predict acute events, such as placental abruption, uterine rupture, or cord prolapse. 

Testing modalities include the non-stress test (NST), amniotic fluid volume (AFV) assessment, BPP (NST and four components measured on ultrasound), and UA Doppler velocimetry. There are numerous maternal, fetal, and placental indications for testing, which are detailed in the table above. Most patients, including those with normal fetal growth, only require an NST and AFV assessment (also known as modified BPP) for regular surveillance. If the modified BPP is abnormal, then a complete BPP is recommended, which includes NST along with ultrasound assessment of fetal breathing, body movements, and tone, and amniotic fluid volume. UA Dopplers assess vascular resistance through the placenta and are reserved for patients with fetal growth restriction, like the patient in the vignette.    

Option Analysis

✅ Biophysical profile (BPP) and umbilical artery (UA) Doppler velocimetry :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Non-stress test (NST) and amniotic fluid volume (AFV) assessment :
Incorrect: NST with AFV assessment is recommended for patients without fetal growth restriction (FGR). This patient has FGR, defined as an EFW of < 10th percentile, so a biophysical profile and umbilical artery Doppler tests are recommended.  
❌ Antepartum fetal surveillance is not indicated in this patient :
Incorrect: This patient has two current indications for surveillance: pregestational diabetes and fetal growth restriction. Her blood pressure is also elevated today, though there is not enough information in the vignette to determine if the patient meets criteria for a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy, which would be another indication for testing.  
❌ Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) assessment and umbilical artery (UA) Doppler velocimetry :
Incorrect: This patient has fetal growth restriction, which is defined as an EFW of < 10th percentile, putting her at greater risk for stillbirth. Therefore, in addition to UA Dopplers, a modified or full biophysical profile (BPP) is recommended, which provides more information than an AFV assessment alone. 
❌ Biophysical profile:
Incorrect:  This patient has fetal growth restriction, which is defined as an EFW of < 10th percentile, putting her at greater risk for stillbirth. Therefore, in addition to a BPP, umbilical artery Doppler velocimetry is also recommended.
